content.content:
# What Are Plug Loads?

## Definition

**Plug loads** (also called miscellaneous electric loads or MELs) are electrical devices plugged into outlets that are not part of HVAC, lighting, or major building systems.

## Examples:
- Computers, monitors, printers
- Kitchen appliances (coffee makers, refrigerators, microwaves)
- Charging devices (phones, laptops)
- Vending machines
- Office equipment (copiers, shredders)
- Personal devices (fans, heaters, lamps)

## Why Plug Loads Matter

**Plug loads now represent 25-35% of commercial building energy** in efficient buildings. As HVAC and lighting have become more efficient, plug loads are a larger share of what remains.

cards.title: Office Buildings
cards.description: Computers and monitors: 40-50%. Copiers/printers: 15-20%. Kitchen/break room: 10-15%. Other: 20-30%.

content.content:
## The Plug Load Challenge

**Unlike HVAC and lighting, plug loads are:**
- Owned/controlled by occupants, not facilities
- Highly distributed (every outlet)
- Diverse (thousands of device types)
- Growing (more personal electronics)
- Often on 24/7 (phantom loads)

**This makes them difficult to manage but also full of opportunity.**

# ENERGY STAR Equipment

## What is ENERGY STAR?

ENERGY STAR is a voluntary EPA program that certifies products meeting energy efficiency criteria. ENERGY STAR products are typically **10-50% more efficient** than standard models.

## Key Product Categories

### Computers & Displays
- Laptops more efficient than desktops
- ENERGY STAR computers have better power management
- Monitors: LED > LCD > older technologies
- All-in-one often more efficient than tower + monitor

### Imaging Equipment
- ENERGY STAR copiers/printers have better sleep modes
- Multifunction devices reduce total equipment count
- Managed print services can reduce print volume

### Commercial Kitchen
- ENERGY STAR refrigerators, ice machines, fryers
- Often 10-30% more efficient
- Significant lifetime savings for 24/7 equipment

items: Require ENERGY STAR for all applicable equipment purchases
Include energy criteria in RFPs and vendor contracts
Consider total cost of ownership (purchase + energy + disposal)
Track equipment inventory and energy use

# Power Management Strategies

## Computer Power Management

**Sleep settings on computers can save 60-70% of idle energy.**

### Recommended Settings:
- Display sleep: 5-15 minutes
- Computer sleep: 15-30 minutes
- Hibernate: After 1-2 hours

### Implementation:
- Group Policy (Windows) or Profile Manager (Mac)
- Network-based management tools
- User education and buy-in

## Smart Power Strips

**Cut phantom/standby power by turning off peripherals when main device is off.**

### Types:
- **Master/controlled**: Peripherals off when master sleeps
- **Occupancy sensing**: All outlets off when no motion
- **Timer-based**: Schedule on/off times
- **Remote/networked**: Central management

### Typical Savings:
- 5-15% of workstation energy
- $20-50 per workstation per year

## Vending Machine Energy

A typical refrigerated vending machine uses **2,500-4,000 kWh/year** ($400-600 at $0.15/kWh).

### Efficiency Options:

**1. VendingMiser/Occupancy Control**
- Turns off lights and compressor when area unoccupied
- Maintains safe temperature, reduces cycling
- Savings: 30-50% = $150-250/year
- Payback: 1-2 years

**2. ENERGY STAR Vending Machines**
- LED lighting, efficient compressor
- Savings: 30-40% vs. standard

**3. Delamping**
- Remove internal lights (no efficiency impact on product)
- Free savings on lighting energy

# Behavioral Energy Programs

## Why Behavior Matters

**Technology alone isn't enough.** Even the most efficient equipment wastes energy if left on unnecessarily.

## Program Elements

### 1. Awareness
- Energy dashboards in common areas
- Regular communication (newsletters, emails)
- Signage near equipment and switches

### 2. Motivation
- Department competitions
- Recognition programs
- Link to sustainability goals
- Share impact metrics

### 3. Enablement
- Easy-to-use controls
- Clear instructions
- Remove barriers to energy-saving actions

### 4. Feedback
- Real-time or near-real-time data
- Comparisons (vs. baseline, vs. peers)
- Celebrate successes

## Typical Results

- Well-designed behavioral programs: **5-15% energy savings**
- Sustained over time with ongoing engagement
- Often the **lowest-cost** efficiency measure
- Bonus: Improves culture and engagement

# Measuring Plug Loads

## Why Measure?

**You can't manage what you don't measure.** Plug loads are often invisible in utility bills because they're mixed with everything else.

## Measurement Options

### Circuit-Level Metering
- Submeters on plug load circuits
- Separates plug loads from other end uses
- Enables trending and comparison

### Outlet-Level Monitoring
- Individual outlet monitors (Kill-A-Watt, etc.)
- Great for audits and identifying big users
- Tedious for ongoing monitoring

### Smart Power Strips with Monitoring
- Measure while controlling
- Per-outlet data in some models
- Networked options for central reporting

### Estimation
- Equipment inventory √ó rated power √ó hours
- Less accurate but better than nothing

## Bundling for OBF

Plug load measures are often too small individually for OBF. Consider bundling:
- Multiple vending machines with misers
- Smart strips as part of workstation upgrade
- Commercial kitchen equipment as package
- Combine with lighting or HVAC project
